Graphic abstract With the guidance of in situ TEM, the high energy density alloyed based anode materials can be realized optimization structure design, thus obtaining excellent electrochemical performances in storing metal ions. Alloyed based anode materials with high theoretical specific capacity and low reaction potential are considered to be highly potential high-energy density anode materials for alkali metal ion batteries (AMIBs). Thus, the design of alloyed based materials with high electrochemical performance has attracted great attention. Among the numerous characterization methods for guiding electrode materials design, in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) gradually plays an irreplaceable role due to its high temporal and spatial resolution in directly observing the change of morphology, crystal structure and element evolutions. Herein, we reviewed the two current research hotspots and mainly focused on the structure design of alloyed based electrode material under the guidance of in situ TEM. Specifically, various nanostructure designs of alloyed based electrode materials with guidance of in situ TEM were employed to solve the key scientific issues of the violent volume change during alloying/dealloying processes for enhanced electrochemical performances. Mainly through introducing buffer space in the electrode material to reduce volume change to improve structural stability, including porous structure (0D), nanotube structure (1D), simple hollow structure, yolk-shell structure and some hybrid hollow structures (3D). Furthermore, the direct guidance of in situ TEM is expected for creating new opportunities to next-generation electrode material design for AMIBs. Keywords In situ TEM Alloyed based anode Nanostructure design Alkali metal ion batteries 1 Introduction In order to alleviate the two major social issues of energy (fossil fuel depletion) and environment (carbon dioxide pollution), vigorously developing renewable energy is the general trend of events, such as solar, tidal, and wind power [1]. However, due to the unevenly distributed and intermittent nature of these energy sources, large-scale energy conversion and storage devices are essential to effectively use these clean energies [2,3]. As an efficient energy storage device, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) exhibit excellent performance in grid energy storage systems (EES) due to its advantages of high energy density, long life, and no memory effect [4,5]. At the same time, LIBs have also been widely used in mobile electronic devices and gradually expanded toward the electric vehicle market in recent years [6]. With the increasing demand in higher energy density and longer cycle life for next-generation EES, in addition to further improve the LIBs system [7], a variety of rechargeable batteries systems have also been developed recently, such as sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) [8,9], potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) [10,11], and so on [12,13]. LIBs, SIBs and PIBs can be collectively called alkali metal ion batteries (AMIBs, M = Li, Na, K), and they show a similar battery reaction mechanism: “rocking chair” mechanism [14–16]. For this type of battery, the energy density depends on theoretical specific capacity and reaction potential of the electrode materials [17,18]. Whether it is a cathode or anode electrode material, a high theoretical specific capacity is conducive to construct the high energy density battery [19]. Additionally, the cathode electrode material with high reaction potential and the anode electrode material with low reaction potential are ideal choices [20]. For anode materials, there are three typical types mechanism for AMIBs based on insertion, conversion, and alloyed mechanism [21]. To be specific, insertion type materials have been widely researched for AMIBs due to their excellent cycling stability. Nevertheless, the relatively low theoretical capacities limit their application in high energy density systems [22]. Additionally, although conversion type materials show higher theoretical capacities for AMIBs, their relatively high battery reaction potentials (>1.0 V) are not beneficial to the construction of high energy density battery systems [23]. Finally, for the alloyed based electrode materials, due to their advantages of high theoretical capacities and low working potential for AMIBs, this type of material was considered as ideal anode materials for high energy density AMIBs [24,25]. Therefore, the alloyed based electrode materials have attracted great attention in recent years. The alloyed based electrode materials are mainly concentrated in Groups IV A (Si, Sn) and V A (P, Sb, Bi) elements [15,26]. When used as an anode electrode material for AMIBs, it will alloy with alkali metal ions during discharge process (xN + yM+ + ye− = M y N x , where M+ represents alkali metal ions and N represents alloyed based electrode materials) [21]. As exhibited in Table 1 , based on the alloying reaction, these anode materials have extremely high theoretical specific capacities [27–33]. Taking the silicon (Si) for lithium storage anode material as an example, each Si atom can be alloyed with 4.4 lithium atoms, providing an ultra-high theoretical lithium storage specific capacity of 4200 mAh g−1 [34]. Furthermore, the working potential of ≈ 0.1–0.6 V versus M+/M provides a sufficiently low anode potential for building a high energy density battery system when matched with cathode materials (e.g., ternary material, LiCoO2) [29]. Therefore, these alloyed based electrode materials are the most promising direction for the development of anode materials toward high energy density AMIBs systems. Unfortunately, these type materials suffer from huge volume expansion/contraction during alloying/dealloying reactions [35]. Theoretical calculation results showed that the volume changes of the alloyed based materials during the reaction with the alkali metal ions are almost more than 200%, and even more than 400% in some cases, such as the lithium storage reaction of Si [36], the sodium storage reaction of phosphorus (P) [37] and the potassium storage reaction of antimony (Sb) [38]. The drastic volume change will cause huge strain inside the electrode materials, resulting in the materials to deform, crack, and pulverize [39]. Furthermore, the electrode materials are easily exfoliated from the current collector when undergoing large volume change, the isolated active materials are unable to contribute the storage metal ion reaction efficiently, resulting in a rapid capacity fade [39]. Another obstacle to the application of alloyed based materials is the unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film. Due to the crack of the electrode materials, the fresh surface will reform a new SEI film during cycling [26]. The increasing thickness of the SEI film will consume additional electrolyte and metal ions, reducing the Coulomb efficiency, increasing the ions transport resistance and further leading the capacity fade of batteries. Meanwhile, the poor conductivity of alloyed based materials is also a nonnegligible problem, which is not conducive to the rapid transport of electrons, resulting in poor rate performance and cycling stability [30]. Over the years, varied strategies have been proposed to overcoming the above-mentioned challenges to improve the electrochemical performances of alloying anode materials [40–44]. Among them two modification approaches are considered to be efficient and widely applied. One effective method is based on the structure design of the electrode materials with suitable structure parameters of morphology, size, porosity and so on [45–47]. In order to relieve the large volume changes during cycling of alloying materials, introducing buffer spaces in the material is an effective way, such as the design of porous and hollow structures, which can improve the structural stability of the material [48,49]. Another approach is coupling the alloyed based materials with conductive materials to form hybrid materials [50–53]. Represented by carbonaceous materials, in alloyed/carbon composite materials, due to the high elastic modulus and high electrical conductivity, carbonaceous materials can effectively alleviate the volumetric strain of the material and improve the electrical conductivity of the composite materials [54–56]. Based on the above strategies, some gratifying results have been achieved under tremendous efforts. Nevertheless, there is still a large gap from the standards of commercial applications for the alloyed based anode materials. Therefore, it is urgent to find a suitable method to guide the material design to further improve the electrochemical performances of alloyed based electrode materials. Recently, with the development of operando characterization technologies, the design of electrode materials has ushered in new opportunities [57–59]. For example, in situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) can monitor the change of crystal structure of electrode materials during cycling [59,60]. The substances and molecular structures information during reaction process can be obtained through in situ Raman [61,62]. And in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) can provide real-time images of material structure changes during battery reaction [63–65]. Notably, due to the high temporal and spatial resolution capabilities and powerful multi-functional extension properties, in situ TEM is an important research method to directly observe the structure changes of electrode materials and guide the materials structure design [66–68]. Currently, there are two methods for in situ TEM testing of electrode materials: open-cell configuration and closed-cell configuration [69–71]. The open-cell configuration is composed of electrode materials, metal anode and electrolyte, of which electrolyte can be solid electrolyte and ionic liquid electrolyte (Fig. 1 (a)) [72]. For the closed-cell configuration, the typical model consists of an electrochemical microchip and a spacer microchip fabricated by a Si wafer as shown in Fig. 1(b) [73]. Comparatively speaking, the nano-battery model of closed-cell configuration is closer to the actual battery system than the open-cell configuration, but the promotion and application of closed-cell technology are limited by the high precision requirements of the equipment and the difficulty of operation [69,74]. Therefore, most of the current researches on electrode materials using in situ TEM were based on open-cell configuration. The classical open-cell configuration case was designed by Li and co-workers [71], the pioneers of in situ TEM in rechargeable ion batteries. In Li’s work, through open-cell in situ TEM testing, the structural changes of SnO2 nanowires during lithiation process were clearly observed. In addition to the direct TEM images, more information about the crystal structure, chemical state, and composition of the electrode materials during charge/discharge processes can be contributed by the multi-functional accessory systems of TEM (Fig. 1(c)). Specifically, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) can be used to analyze the crystal structure changes of electrode materials during the alloying/dealloying processes [75]. The electron energy loss spectrum spectroscopy (EELS) results can analyze the elemental composition, chemical bond and electronic structure of the materials, which is beneficial to explore the composition and chemical state of the electrode materials during the electrochemical reaction [76]. And the energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) can be used to obtain information on the element types and contents of electrode materials in different reaction states [71]. Based on these in situ TEM multi-functional characterizations, the morphology, crystal structure, and chemical composition of the electrode materials during electrochemical reaction can be directly visualized and analyzed, promoting the exploration of energy storage mechanism and directly guiding the structure design of electrode materials. There are several excellent reviews have detailed discussed the research progress of alloyed based electrode materials in AMIBs [24–27,39,77], and also some reports have summarized the application of in situ TEM in electrochemical energy storage [63–66,69,78–80]. For example, Buschbaum et al. [24] summarized the development history of several representative alloyed based anode materials of Sn, Sb, and Ge and conducted an in-depth analysis of this type of material. Very recently, He et al. [79] focused on the application of in situ TEM in rechargeable ion batteries and dedicated discussed how to use in situ TEM to analyze and solve the fundamental questions of conversion type materials. In this review, we combine the two current research hotspots and mainly focus on the structure design of alloyed based electrode material under the guidance of in situ TEM. Specifically, we will mainly introduce the application of in situ TEM in guiding the nanostructure design of alloyed based electrode materials for AMIBs to obtain enhanced electrochemical performances in recent years. Finally, a development trend of applying in situ characterization techniques and theoretical calculation in guiding material design is prospected. 2 Structure design of alloyed based electrode materials 2.1 Solid structure Electrode materials with solid structures such as bulk, particle, and fiber, are usually easier to prepare, and these structures are beneficial to provide high volumetric energy density [81–85]. For alloyed based electrode materials with high theoretical specific capacity, the extremely large volume expansion during the alloying reaction with alkali metal ions will bring great stress and strain to the solid structure material, resulting in the material to be cracked, even pulverized [86–88]. To mitigate this issue, designing electrode materials into small-sized nanostructures (nanoparticles, nanowires and nanosheets) has proven as an effective way, which can reduce the stress and strain of the material structure to increase the structural stability of the material during alloying/dealloying reactions [89–92]. Furthermore, the small-size structure is conducive to the rapid transport of alkali metal ions, improving the electrochemical performances of the alloyed based electrode material for storing alkali metal ions [93–95]. In order to understand the relationship between the size of solid nanoparticles and structural stability of alloyed based electrode materials, Huang et al. [96] used spherical silicon nanoparticles as the research object. A series of silicon nanoparticles with different sizes (tens of nanometers to a few microns) were prepared for the anode materials of LIBs. Notably, in situ TEM was employed to explore the structural changes of solid silicon nanoparticles with different diameters during the first lithiation process. The results showed that whether the silicon nanoparticles cracked or fractured during the first lithiation process depended on the particle size. And there is a critical diameter of about 150 nm, below which the silicon nanoparticles can keep the structure intact without cracked during the first lithiation process, while the large silicon particles above the critical value will be severely cracked or fractured upon lithiation (Fig. 2 (a)). Specifically, Fig. 2(b) shows the in situ TEM observation results of a silicon nanoparticle with a diameter of 940 nm (larger than critical size) during the first lithiation process. The lithiation process starts from the surface of the particles. A layer of Li x Si shell was formed and uniformly covering the surface of the Si particles within 2 min. As the lithiation continued, a crack appears near the surface (157 s), and new cracks gradually emerged and extended inward the particle. With the growth of numerous cracks, the nanoparticles eventually fracture into several fragments (273 s). In addition, the SADE results illustrated that the monocrystalline silicon final transform into polycrystalline Li15Si4 after the lithiation process. Besides, Si nanowires were also taken as the research object to study the structural changes of 1D solid structures during the alloying/dealloying reactions [72]. The directly observed results showed that the alloying process of Si to form Li15Si4 existed a large volume expansion, and highly anisotropic way occurred in the independent nanowire < 112 > direction, resulting in a middle dumbbell-shaped cross section. Although the lithium products of silicon nanowires showed good plasticity, the huge volume changes during the alloying process still caused great stress inside the structure, which eventually led to the instability and fracture of nanowires structure. The in situ TEM results directly proved that the solid structure of the alloyed based anode materials will occur great volume expansion during the alloying reaction, resulting in structural fracture, which is fatal to the cycling stability of high capacity batteries. Silicon based lithium storage is a typical example of alloying anode materials for alkali metal ion batteries. Therefore, it can be inferred that other alloyed based anode materials will occur similar situations when storing alkali metal ions. For this reason, it is essential to carry out reasonable structure design of alloyed based anode materials to alleviate the volume change of materials during the alloying/dealloying reactions, thereby improving the electrochemical performances of the electrode materials. 2.2 Porous structure From the discussion in the Section 2.1, it can be seen that solid alloyed based materials with large particle sizes are easily fractured during alloying/dealloying processes. Designing electrode materials with porous structure is a common method to alleviate this problem. In this section, we summarize some classic cases of using in situ TEM to guide the design of porous structure of alloyed based materials for AMIBs. Porous structure means that the material has a network structure with interconnected or closed pores [97]. According to the pore size, the pore structures can be divided into micropores (<2 nm), mesopores (2–50 nm) and macropores (>50 nm) [98–100]. As electrode materials for AMIBs, porous structure can provide buffer space for alloyed based anode materials to ease the volume change during the cycling [101]. In addition, the porous structure creates a huge contact area for the active material and electrolyte, which is conducive to the diffusion of metal ions [102,103]. Furthermore, the porous structure can effectively improve the utilization of active materials [104,105]. Therefore, many cutting-edge structure designs are developed around porous structures [106,107], and lots of advanced characterization methods such as in situ TEM have been reasonably applied to guide the structure design [108,109]. Kim and co-workers designed mesoporous Si/C microspheres through combining the magnesiothermic reduction of porous silica and the chemical vapor deposition of thin carbon layers [110]. The mesoporous Si/C microspheres was composed of numerous ~ 10 nm primary Si nanocrystals coated with a graphitic carbon layer, forming a large number of internal pore structures (Fig. 3 (a)). As shown in the expected schematic, the volume expansion of mesoporous Si/C during charge/discharge processes can be effectively suppressed by the internal pore structure constructed by carbon coated Si nanocrystals. Notably, in situ TEM was used to observe the lithiation process of mesoporous Si/C. As exhibited in Fig. 3(b), the pore structure of the mesoporous Si/C is gradually filled with expanded active material during the lithiation process. After fully alloying with lithium, the volume expansion rate is only ~ 85%, which is much smaller than the theoretical value of lithiation volume expansion of solid silicon particles. This result illustrated the effectiveness of the structure design in alleviating volume expansion, improving the structural stability of the material. Based on this rational design, when used as an anode electrode material for LIBs, mesoporous Si/C showed excellent cycling stability. After activating at a current density of 50 mA g−1, an initial capacity of 1102 mAh g−1 was obtained at 1.0 A g−1, and maintaining a high reversible specific capacity of 990 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles (Fig. 3(c)). Later, He et al. [111] applied this strategy to the design of another composite alloyed based anode material: SnSb. And the difference was that a porous conductive substrate was constructed for the active material instead of directly constructing a porous active material. As shown in Fig. 3(d), through combining spray drying and space-confined catalysis, a composite of SnSb-in-plane nanoconfined 3D N-doped porous graphene network (3D SnSb@N-PG) was prepared for AMIBs anode material. In order to explore structural changes of the composite materials during storing metal ions, a nano lithium-ion battery was constructed for in situ TEM observation. As can be seen in Fig. 3(e), the contrast of SnSb nanocrystals gradually weakened during the alloying reaction, indicating that the nanocrystals gradually transformed into polycrystalline Li x Sn and Li x Sb alloy. Notably, these nanocrystals recovered well to their original state after completely dealloying, and there were no undesirable phenomena such as structural damage and particle agglomeration. This result shows that the designed composite material has excellent structural stability during the alloying/dealloying reactions with lithium. Furthermore, when employed as an anode material for SIBs, it also exhibited excellent electrochemical performances. Significantly, the 3D SnSb@N-PG electrode exhibits excellent long-life and high cycle stability when cycling at a high current density of 10 A g−1, a high capacity of about 190 mAh g−1 was delivered and maintained 4000 cycles with a capacity retention rate near 100% (Fig. 3(f)). A large number of research results showed that the alloyed based electrode materials with porous structure exhibit better cycling performance than of the solid electrode materials. The in situ TEM characterization results showed that this phenomenon can be attributed to the porous structure can effectively mitigate the volume change of the alloyed based materials during the alloying/dealloying reactions, leading to an improved structural stability of alloyed based electrode materials. 2.3 Simple hollow structure In addition to the porous structure mentioned above, simple hollow structure is another common design for alleviating the volume expansion of alloyed based anode materials during alloying reaction [35,112]. Particularly, the simple hollow structure can be defined as a structure consists of single shell without any confinement [113]. This type structure also can provide sufficient buffer space for the volume expansion of the active material to improve the structural stability of the electrode material during cycling [114]. Therefore, simple hollow structure is also widely used in alloyed based anode materials [115]. There are two typical strategies for designing simple hollow structures of alloyed based materials. The common approach is that direct preparation of hollow alloyed based materials for subsequent employment as electrode materials [116]. On the other hand, designing a solid alloyed based material with a specific size effect, which would form a hollow structure spontaneously during alloying/dealloying reaction processes [117]. For example, the sodium storage behavior of red phosphorus was explored as a typical case by Kim and co-workers [116]. Owning to the large volume expansion during sodiation (~400 %) and low electrical conductivity (≈10−14 S cm−1) of red phosphorus, combining structure design and hybridizing with conductive materials is a common approach to optimize the electrochemical performances. In Kim’s work, a hollow porous carbon nanospheres (HPCNSs) have rational designed as host for phosphorous through vaporization-condensation method. Then, a nano sodium-ion battery was constructed for in situ TEM observing the structure changes of materials during sodiation/desodiation processes. The in situ TEM results showed that with the buffer of the huge space inside the hollow material, the volume expansion of HPCNS/P composite after full sodiation is only 67.3%, which is much smaller than the theoretical value, being beneficial to improve the structural stability and cycling performance of the P based anode materials. When employing as anode material for SIBs, the HPCNS/P composite exhibited clearly optimized sodium storage performances. At a high current density of 1.0 A g−1, the P based anode material had a final capacity of 548 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles, with a high capacity retention rate over 76%. For another strategy, McDowell et al. [117] took Sb as the research object to design an alloyed based material that spontaneously forms hollow structure during cycling. Sb nanoparticles of diameter 15.7 ± 2.5 nm with a native oxide of thickness ~ 2 nm were prepared. In situ TEM was used to demonstrate that the as-prepared solid Sb nanoparticles would spontaneously form uniform voids during delithiation process, and these voids could be reversibly filled and vacated during subsequent cycling (Fig. 4 (a)). Concretely, the nanoparticles gradually become larger during the lithiation process, and in the subsequent delithiation process, the nanoparticles spontaneously form a cavity structure in the middle of the particles, which is supported by the Sb shell inside the surface oxide layer. Interestingly, in the continuing lithiation process, the Sb shell expanded to fill the inter cavity without destroying the surface oxide layer (Fig. 4(b)). And SAED patterns were carried out to analyze the crystal structure change of Sb nanoparticles during alloying/dealloying processes (Fig. 4(c)). Due to the unique characteristics of spontaneously forming void to stabilize the structure, the designed Sb nanocrystals exhibited excellent cycle stability when used as anode materials for LIBs. Under a high current density (660 mA g−1) of 1C (1C = charge/discharge in 1 h), the Sb nanocrystals showed a high reversible capacity close to the theoretical value (660 mAh g−1) within 100 cycles while the Sb bulk showed capacity decay (Fig. 4(d)). Importantly, the Sb nanocrystals showed higher Coulomb efficiency due to the high stability of the surface oxide layer. The authors also explained that the smaller Sb particles spontaneously form hollow structure during cycling can be attributed to the mechanical constraint of the outer oxide layer. Specifically, when Li ions removed from the fully alloyed Li-Sb particles, the volume of the Li-Sb phase in the inner core begins to shrink, creating compressive stress on the outer oxide layer. As a result, the outer oxide layer will exert increased tension to the inside of the particles, which will tend to induce the formation of hollow structure. In situ TEM observation results showed that the hollow structure can effectively alleviate the overall volume change of the alloyed based electrode based on the larger internal space. However, the shell of the hollow structure still undergoes significant volume changes. Hybridizing with elastic materials can improve the stability of hollow structures, which can protect the hollow structure from being destroyed during cycling, ensuring the effectiveness of the hollow structure design. Therefore, stable hollow structure design is useful approach to improve the electrochemical performances of alloyed based materials for AMIBs. 2.4 Yolk-shell structure The simple hollow structure has been proved as an effective design to improve the energy storage performances of alloyed based electrode materials. It should be noted that the simple hollow structure has a large internal cavity, the insufficient utilization of internal space will result in a low volumetric energy density of the batteries [118]. Complex hollow structures design is proposed to improve the volumetric energy density of hollow alloyed based electrode materials. Yolk-shell structure is a typical complex hollow structure consisting of an inner core and an outer shell [118,119]. For the electrode materials, the inner core is generally a high-capacity active material, and the outer shell is generally a conductive material [50,120]. The high conductivity and mechanical elasticity of the external layer are utilized to modify the internal active material for enhancing electrochemical performances [121]. Particularly, the space between the inner core and the outer shell can effectively alleviate the stress and strain of the inner active material during the electrochemical reaction [49]. The large space can also be fully utilized by the internal active materials, increasing the tap density of the electrode materials [82,122]. Due to the above advantages, the yolk-shell structure is widely used in the modification of alloyed based anode materials. Lithium storage in silicon-based materials is still a classic case for yolk-shell structure design. Cui and co-workers [123] designed a secondary structure for silicon-based materials with silicon nanoparticles were individually wrapped by carbon skeleton and assembled into highly spherical pomegranate microbeads. Importantly, in situ TEM was used to guide the internal void space design between the carbon shell and encapsulated silicon nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), the left area is silicon pomegranate with a gap size of ~ 15 nm. The in situ TEM results show that the structure of composite material was cracked after lithiation, which can be attributed to the insufficient internal space for buffering the volume expansion of silicon during the lithiation process. After adjustment the internal space, the silicon pomegranate with internal space of ~ 40 nm can keep the material structure from being damaged after the alloying reaction (the right area of Fig. 5(a)). Furthermore, the diameter of silicon pomegranate showed an expansion ratio of only ~ 10% (from 3.1 to 3.4 μm) during cycling (Fig. 5(b)). Due to the reasonable overall structure and precise void design, the silicon pomegranate exhibited significantly optimized lithium storage stability. At a rate of C/2, a high reversible capacity of 1160 mAh g−1 still maintained after 1000 cycles (Fig. 5(c)). In addition to LIBs systems, the application of yolk-shell structures also attracted great attention in new EES such as SIBs. Li et al. [120] designed a well-defined yolk-shell model and applied to antimony-based anode materials (Sb@C) for SIBs. In situ TEM snapshots showed that yolk-shell structure had effectively mitigate the pulverization of the inner Sb nanoparticles while the bare Sb nanoparticle was fractured upon sodiation. Due to the structural advantages, yolk-shell Sb@C showed significantly optimized sodium storage rate performance and cycling stability. Similarly, Yu and Zhang et al. [124] used in situ TEM guidance to design a yolk-shell Bi@Void@C composite material with an optimized void space structure, which not only aimed at alleviating the volume expansion of inner Bi nanoparticles, but designing a hollow structure with high volume energy density. The in situ TEM results showed that after repeated sodiation/desodiation reactions for three cycling (Fig. 5(d)), no cracks and fractures were observed in the well-designed nanostructures, indicating that the Bi@Void@C possesses excellent structural stability, which lays the foundation for the cyclic stability of the anode material. When used as anode materials for SIBs, the Bi@Void@C-2 exhibited an excellent cycling stability of delivering reversible capacities of 253 mAh g−1 at high current density of 1.0 A g−1 (Fig. 5(e)), which is better than that of Bi@Void@C-1 (insufficient internal space) and Bi@Void@C-3 (excessive internal space), realizing the yolk-shell structure design with high volume energy density. Under the guidance of in situ TEM, the reasonably designed alloyed based electrode materials with yolk-shell structure not only exhibited excellent cycling performance, but the volume energy density was also significantly improved due to the high utilization of the internal space. Therefore, the yolk-shell structure is a useful structure design to optimize the overall performances of the hollow alloyed based electrode materials for AMIBs. 2.5 Nanotube structure Compared with the above-mentioned zero-dimensional (0D) nanoparticles and three-dimensional (3D) porous/hollow structures, one-dimensional (1D) nanotube structure is widely used in the field of energy storage due to their unique advantages: (1) Shortening the diffusion of metal ions for fast diffusion kinetic; (2) providing a direct current pathway for electrical transport; (3) accommodating the volume change during electrochemical reactions; (4) acting as a host for filling other materials [125,126]. Generally, the design of nanotube structure in alloyed based materials can be mainly summarized into two categories. One is that constructing a porous nanotube conductive material as the host for alloyed based material to realize the structure design [51,127]; the other is that the alloyed based material and the conductive material coaxially form nanotubes composites [128,129]. Yu and Zhang et al. [130] designed the above-mentioned nanotube structures based on red phosphorus and carbon composite materials as anode materials for emerging PIBs. Particularly, the vaporization-condensation method was used to uniformly encapsulate the red P nanoparticles into the porous carbon nanotube conductive carrier to form red P@N-PHCNFs. As comparison, the same method was employed to coat red P nanoparticles on the inner and outer walls of non-porous carbon nanotubes to obtain coaxially red P/N-PHCNFs (Fig. 6 (a)). In this case, due the alloyed active material of red P/N-PHCNFs was exposed on the surface of the carbon-based material, which is not effectively protected and is easily damaged during the cycle. While the red P nanoparticles in red P@N-PHCNFs are evenly embedded in the porous of the carbon nanotube, which could be confirmed by the line-scan element distribution of EDS (Fig. 6(b)). Therefore, the porous carbon nanotubes played a good protective role for red P during alloying/dealloying processes, improving the structural stability of the composite material. This statement was further verified by in situ TEM results (Fig. 6(c)). Upon potassiation process, the thickness of the red P@N-PHCNFs nanotube wall expanded from 74 to 93 nm with a low volume expansion ratio of only 26%, verifying that the designed porous nanotube structure can effectively alleviate the volume change of the material. Importantly, no undesirable changes such as cracks were observed in the structure, demonstrating that the red P@N-PHCNFs have excellent structural stability. Attributed to the above advantages, red P@N-PHCNFs showed excellent potassium storage performances. Under a high current density of 5.0 A g−1, a high reversible capacity of 342 mAh g−1 can be obtained, and a high specific capacity of 740 mAh g−1 was maintained for 60 cycles in subsequent cycle (0.1 A g−1) (Fig. 6(d)). For the alloyed based material and the conductive material coaxially form nanotubes, the combination of conductive materials coated on the outer surface of alloyed based active materials can more effectively improve the electrochemical performances of the materials. Lou and co-worker [131] designed Sb@C coaxial nanotubes through coupling carbon-coating and thermal-reduction strategy. With the mitigation effect of the nanotube inner space upon Sb the sodiation process, and the structural protection and conductivity improvement of the outer carbon shell, the well-designed Sb@C nanotubes showed excellent sodium storage performances. Specifically, a stable capacity of 240 mAh g−1 can be maintained at a high current density of 1.0 A g−1 after 2000 cycles. Interestingly, for alloyed based materials with nanotube structure, the expansion direction of the tube wall during the alloying reaction was also carefully studied. Wang et al. [132] chose amorphous-Si (a-Si) nanotubes as a typical research model, combined with in situ TEM to analyze the expansion direction of the silicon nanotube wall during the lithiation process. The results clarified that only the outer surface expands outward while no significant change occurs in the inner surface after the full lithiation of a-Si nanotubes with natural oxide layers. When the thickness of SiO x on the outer surface was artificially increased, the lithiated nanotubes will be induced expand inwardly by mechanical confinement effects, significantly reducing the overall outward expansion of materials. Furthermore, the outer SiO x coating showed no effect on the lithiation mechanism of Si nanotubes. This work revealed the effect of surface coating on the volume change of nanotubes, providing inspiration for the design of alloyed based materials with other hollow structures.The nanotube structure combines the advantages of 1D structure in promoting electron/ion transport and hollow structure in alleviating volume changes during cycling. It is popular in the structure design of alloyed based electrode materials. Furthermore, under the guidance of in situ TEM in recent years, nanotube structure with optimized design has played an important role in development of alloyed based electrode materials. 2.6 Hybrid hollow structure In addition to simple nanotube structures, some complex hollow 1D structures combined nanofiber with porous, yolk-shell, and other hollow structures, have also attracted lots of attention due to their unique advantages, such as porous nanofiber [133], hybrid hollow nanofiber [134] and so on [135]. For these complex hollow 1D structures, except the advantages of a 1D structure for the rapid diffusion of electron/ions, some unique characteristics also combined from the hybrid structures (porous structure, yolk-shell structure, etc.) [136,137]. Therefore, various hybrid hollow 1D structures are designed to improve the electrochemical performances of alloyed based anode materials under the guidance of in situ TEM. Wang et al. [133] designed silica-reinforced porous carbon nanofibers with encapsulated Sb nanoparticles through electrospinning and subsequent thermal reduction. In this hybrid porous nanofiber, silica showed good compatibility with carbon nanofiber and it can obviously enhance the stability of fiber structure. And the porous structure within the carbon nanofiber can efficiently buffers the volume changes of the encapsulated Sb nanoparticles during alloying/dealloying processes. Furthermore, the overall porous nanofiber structure could allow for fast diffusion of electron/ions. In situ TEM was carried out to analyze the structural and phase changes of the SiO2/Sb@CNF electrode during cycling. During the lithiation/delithiation processes, only expansion/contraction of the embedded Sb nanoparticles in nanofibers was observed, while no obvious change occurred on the overall porous nanofiber structure, revealing that the well-designed hybrid porous nanofiber structure could withstand severe volume changes and is an ideal carrier for alloyed based anode materials. Due to these favorable designs, the SiO2/Sb@CNF electrode showed excellent lithium storage stability. A high reversible capacity of 468 mAh g−1 can maintain for more than 400 cycles at a high current density of 1000 mA g−1. Our recent work precisely designed a hybrid hollow nanofiber of yolk-shell Sb@C nanoboxes embedded in carbon nanofibers (Sb@CNFs), which was fabricated through coupling a metal–organic frameworks (MOFs)-engaged conversion strategy with a subsequent thermal reduction [138]. This design cleverly integrated yolk-shell structure and nanofiber structure, effectively improving the potassium storage performances of Sb@CNFs. Particularly, a nano potassium-ions battery was constructed with the as-prepared Sb@CNFs and metal potassium for in situ TEM analysis, in which a K2O layer on metal surface was acted as a solid electrolyte (Fig. 7 (a)). Furthermore, the schematic diagram of expected structural changes during alloying/dealloying processes of Sb@CNFs was shown in Fig. 7(b), the internal Sb nanoparticles would undergo violent volume expansion/shrinkage during potassiation/depotassiation processes, while the void space could effectively alleviate the volume change, and the plastic carbon shell protected the overall structure from damage. Notably, during the potassiation process (Fig. 7(c)), potassium ions transported along the carbon fiber and then penetrate into the yolk-shell Sb@C nanobox. The Sb nanoparticles gradually expanded and almost filled the internal void space of the carbon shell at 60 min. Importantly, the volume expansion of Sb nanoparticles was about 404%, while the expansion ratio of the overall carbon shell was only about 220%, indicating that the void space in the yolk-shell structure could effectively relieve the overall volume expansion of the Sb based material during the potassiation process. Subsequently, the volume of Sb@C nanobox gradually shrank during the depotassiation process, but it cannot be completely restored to the initial state, which can be attributed to the irreversible reaction of potassium ions with Sb and CNFs (Fig. 7(d)). Notably, after repeated potassiation/depotassiation reactions twice, the overall structure of the Sb@CNFs remained intact without any cracks, indicating that the hybrid design yolk-shell Sb@C nanoboxes embedded in carbon nanofibers showed high structural stability. Thus, Sb@CNFs electrode exhibited excellent cycling stability with a high capacity of 338 mAh g−1 at 200 mA g−1 after 200 cycles when used as the anode of PIBs (Fig. 7(e)). To sum up, a single hollow structure has its unique advantages, and accompanied with unavoidable problems, such as the poor durability of hollow structures. The above-mentioned studies demonstrate that the rational designed hybrid hollow structure can realize the coupling of different structures. In addition to fully demonstrating their respective structural advantages, the synergy effect between different structures can achieve complementary advantages, providing more favorable conditions for the transport and storage of alkali metal ions, thus further improving the electrochemical performances of alloyed based electrode materials. 3 Conclusions and outlook This article mainly focuses on in situ TEM guiding the structure design of alloyed based AMIBs anode materials. The direct observation of in situ TEM shows that introducing buffer space into the electrode materials can effectively alleviate the volume change of alloyed based anode materials during the alloying/dealloying processes, which can significantly enhance the structural stability of the electrode materials, thereby improving the electrochemical performances in storing alkali metal ions. Furthermore, with the assistance functions of TEM, such as SAED, EELS and EDS, in situ TEM not only discloses the structural changes of alloyed based anode materials during the reaction process, other information related to the reaction mechanism such as crystal structure, element valence and distribution can also be obtained at the same time, promoting the exploration of energy storage mechanism of the alloyed based anode materials. Specifically, the common designs for introducing buffer space are generally various hollow structures, such as porous structure (0D), nanotube structure (1D), simple hollow structure, yolk-shell structure and some hybrid hollow structures (3D). In addition to alleviating volume changes, these reasonable designs can also increase the surface area to more electrochemically active sites, shorten the ion/electron transport path to improve the reaction kinetics. To sum up, with the guidance of the multifunctional in situ TEM, numerous precise and ingenious structure designs were realized to efficiently solve the key problems existing in alloyed based electrode materials of AMIBs. Meanwhile, there are also some problems in the current in situ TEM characterization technology, which need to be further developed and solved. First, the negative effects of electronic radiation cannot be ignored. The high-energy electron beam radiation will destroy the unstable electrode materials. In recent years, with the invention of cryo-TEM and the development of imaging technology for low accelerating voltage [139–141], the in situ observation opportunity have been extended to the electrode materials with poor thermostability. Thus, this is an attractive area for further exploration. Furthermore, there are still significant differences between the nanobatteries model and the actual batteries. In the commonly open-cell configuration the contact between the electrolyte and the electrode is solid point contact, some important scientific issues occurring in solid–liquid interface of the actual battery cannot be analyzed. In addition, quantitative analysis is difficult to achieve in the open-cell due the amount of electrode material used in constructing the nanobattery cannot be accurately measured. Clear analysis of solid–liquid interface and quantitative analysis are highly anticipated in closed-cell configuration, which is considered as a nanobattery model closer to the actual battery, but the current technology development of closed-cell is not yet mature. For example, the organic electrolyte may be decomposed due to sensitive to high voltage electron beams and the kinetics is more sensitive according to the electrolyte condition than the electrodes due to the long distance between the two electrode materials in closed-cell configuration. In summary, in situ TEM is becoming a feasible characterization technology to directly observe and analyze the morphology, crystal structure and chemical evolution of electrode materials during reaction process. With the guidance of in situ TEM, the high energy density alloyed based anode material can be realized precise optimization structure design, thus obtaining excellent electrochemical performances in storing alkali metal ions. Besides, theoretical simulation has been widely used in materials design and analysis due to its high efficiency, reliability, and specificity [142,143]. Theoretical analysis can do a lot of simulation experimental analysis that cannot be completed in reality, which provides great guidance for experimental design. Thus, theoretical simulation also plays an increasingly important role in guiding materials design. Combining these two guidance methods of theoretical simulation and in situ TEM, more optimized alloyed based electrode materials design is expected. Furthermore, the rapid development of theoretical calculation and in situ TEM will provide better theoretical and technical foundation for the exploitation of electrode materials for the next generation high energy density EES. coredata.dc:description: Alloyed based anode materials with high theoretical specific capacity and low reaction potential are considered to be highly potential high-energy density anode materials for alkali metal ion batteries (AMIBs). Thus, the design of alloyed based materials with high electrochemical performance has attracted great attention. Among the numerous characterization methods for guiding electrode materials design, in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) gradually plays an irreplaceable role due to its high temporal and spatial resolution in directly observing the change of morphology, crystal structure and element evolutions. Herein, we reviewed the two current research hotspots and mainly focused on the structure design of alloyed based electrode material under the guidance of in situ TEM. Specifically, various nanostructure designs of alloyed based electrode materials with guidance of in situ TEM were employed to solve the key scientific issues of the violent volume change during alloying/dealloying processes for enhanced electrochemical performances. Mainly through introducing buffer space in the electrode material to reduce volume change to improve structural stability, including porous structure (0D), nanotube structure (1D), simple hollow structure, yolk-shell structure and some hybrid hollow structures (3D). Furthermore, the direct guidance of in situ TEM is expected for creating new opportunities to next-generation electrode material design for AMIBs.

coredata.dc:title: Revealing the structure design of alloyed based electrodes for alkali metal ion batteries with in situ TEM
